Time Warner (TWX) is gearing up for an epic battle this Sunday on HBO's "Game of Thrones," but it's Viacom (VIAB), Walt Disney (DIS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) that are engaged in shuffles at the top.Sumner Redstone's National Amusements, which holds about 80% of Viacom's voting stock, said late Thursday that it would ax five members of the board, including current Viacom CEO Philippe Dauman.One of the affected directors, Frederic Salerno, has filed suit to seek "an expedited determination that Shari Redstone's attempted removal and replacement of Viacom directors is invalid and that the directors elected at the 2016 Annual Meeting continue to serve."Redstone has reportedly lost confidence in Dauman and the current board, but critics question the 93-year-old's mental soundness and whether his daughter and current board member, Shari, is pulling strings behind the scenes."If the changes to the composition of the board are upheld in court, it seems clear that Sumner Redstone will at some point seek to replace Philippe Dauman as CEO of the company," wrote Credit Suisse analyst Omar Sheikh.The five new directors include Buzzfeed Chairman Kenneth Lerer, former Sony (SNE) Entertainment President Nicole Seligman and former DreamWorks SKG co-COO and current Avis Budget Group (CAR) Executive Chairman Ronald Nelson.RBC upgraded Viacom to sector perform from underperform on the leadership shuffle.Viacom also issued guidance early Friday, with expectations of $1-$1.05 in per-share adjusted diluted earnings for the third quarter and 4% domestic ad sales declines. The outlook falls well short of current analyst views for $1.38 EPS.Viacom, which soared late Thursday on the board shake-up on hopes for a change in direction for the struggling cable and movie empire, closed down 1.4%.Meanwhile, Fox on Thursday named current Twentieth Century Fox Co-Chairman Stacey Snider as the new chairman and CEO of the movie studio, with current head Jim Gianopulos to step down on June 30, 2017, and transition to a "strategic role," said the company in a statement.The move comes amid $250 million in anticipated cost cuts, announced in February, that reportedly includes staff reductions in Fox's TV and film units.James Murdoch, rose to succeed his father Rupert as CEO of 21st Century Fox last year. His brother Lachlan Murdoch serves alongside Rupert Murdoch as executive co-chairman.Shares fell 1.1% to 28.81 on Friday.Separately, Walt Disney's CEO succession plan is still murky after Tom Staggs stepped down in April as COO of the media conglomerate. CEO Bob Iger is slated to remain head of the House of Mouse through 2018.Disney stock rose 0.6%.Time Warner appears clear of C-suite changes, but HBO in May said that Casey Bloys would become president of HBO programming, succeeding Michael Lombardo.Reports recently surfaced that Apple (AAPL) and Time Warner execs had briefly entertained the idea of Apple acquiring Time Warner, though talks did not reach the level of chief execs Tim Cook or Jeff Bewkes.Time Warner shares climbed 1.4%. Apple shares fell 2.3%.

Shares of Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), Zillow (Z) United Natural Foods (UNFI), FedEx (FDX), Viacom (VIAB) and Hawaiian Airlines (HA) are moving after hours Monday. Here's why:Alexion Pharmaceuticals sank 11% following disappointing results from a Phase 3 trial involving its drug Soliris. The company said the primary endpoint of a study examining Soliris’ use for patients with a rare neuromuscular disorder “missed statistical significance.”The study was for patients with refractory generalized myasthenia gravis, a disorder that causes people to have “profound muscle weakness throughout the body,” the company said.Alexion said it continues to examine the data from the study and would present detailed results on July 7 during the 14th International Congress on Neuromuscular Diseases in Toronto, according to a company statement.Zillow said it has settled a lawsuit brought by News Corp. (NWSA)-owned Move, the National Association of Realtors, and three related entities for $130 millon. The real estate information site, which admitted no wrongdoing, had been accused by Move of stealing trade secrets by hiring two Move executives. The lawsuit had sought $2 billion in damages.Zillow stock rose nearly 8% after closing up 3.4% to 30.33.The food distributor said per-share profit fell over 8% to 76 cents in Q3, nevertheless beating analyst views for 66 cents a share. But revenue edged up less than 1% to $2.13 billion, falling short of estimates for $2.16 billion.United Natural Foods guided up its full-year EPS forecast to $2.47-$2.53 and net sales to $8.46 billion-$8.5 billion vs. prior guidance for EPS of $2.34-$2.44 on sales of $8.31 billion-$8.43 billion.United Natural Foods Shares jumped more than 10%.Sumner Redstone’s National Amusements, which owns 80% of Viacom’s voting stock, amended Viacom’s corporate bylaws to state that “any sale or financial transaction affecting all or a portion of Paramount Pictures must be unanimously approved by the Viacom Board of Directors.”Shares dipped 0.15%.The company announced a 40-cent per-share quarterly cash dividend. FedEx shares edged up 0.6%.Hawaiian Airlines said May passenger traffic rose 4.9%, outpacing flight capacity growth of 0.3%. Load factor increased 3.8 percentage points to 84.3%.Shares were little changed late.

Netflix (NFLX) stock tumbled on Tuesday, a day after the Internet TV network posted mixed first-quarter results and gave disappointing guidance for the current quarter.Netflix shares were down 11%, below 97, in early afternoon trading on the stock market today. The stock fell below its 50-day moving average, a key technical support level.Late Monday, Netflix posted Q1 earnings per share that beat forecasts, but came up short on revenue.It earned six cents a share, up 20% year over year, on sales of $1.958 billion, up 24%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were looking for three cents EPS on sales of $1.965 billion.For the second quarter, Netflix is targeting earnings per share of two cents. It did not give a revenue estimate. Wall Street had been modeling Netflix to earn five cents a share, down 17%, on sales of $2.117 billion, up 29%.IBD Take: Netflix has often been a highly rated stock, though now its ratings are mixed.The Los Gatos, Calif.-based company gained 6.74 million total streaming subscribers worldwide in Q1, topping its guidance for 6.1 million. It added 2.23 million streaming subscribers in the U.S. and 4.51 million in foreign markets. It ended the quarter with 81.5 million subscribers worldwide.What follows are five key takeaways from Netflix’s Q1 report.Netflix expects to add 2.5 million new subscribers in Q2, its seasonally weakest quarter. That would be its lowest new subscriber total in two years, even though Netflix has since rolled out its service worldwide, excluding China.Netflix projects that it will add 500,000 streaming subscribers in the U.S. and 2 million in international markets in Q2.Netflix faces increased subscriber churn in the U.S. as many longtime customers see a $2 increase in their monthly fee to $9.99 a month, starting next month. Over the last two years as Netflix adjusted its pricing, it grandfathered existing customers at the earlier rates.Meanwhile, Netflix's international subscriber forecast for Q2 faces tough comparisons to the year-earlier quarter, when the company launched in Australia and New Zealand.On a conference call with analysts to discuss Q1 earnings late Monday, Netflix CEO Reed Hastings said that the company plans to roll out price increases over the rest of the year to those U.S. customers given generous grace periods.Currently, more than half of Netflix’s U.S. subscribers pay only $7.99 or $8.99 for the company’s most popular plan, now priced at $9.99 a month. The plan provides HD video streams to two devices at a time.Netflix ended Q1 with nearly 47 million U.S. streaming subscribers.“We will phase out this grandfathering gradually over the remainder of 2016, with our longest-tenured members getting the longest benefit,” the company said in a statement. “We are rolling this out slowly over the year, rather than mostly in May, so we can learn as we go.”Well-heeled, better-educated consumers fueled Netflix's early growth in overseas markets. The streaming video leader first grabbed the low-hanging fruit: consumers who enjoy English-language content and have international credit cards.Getting the next group of consumers to subscribe will take more work, the company said. Netflix needs to add more content in local languages and new payment options, Hastings said.“Over the next couple of years, as we further localize, we’ll be able to see more opportunity,” Hasting said.Netflix will premiere its first French original series, “Marseille,” a political drama starring Gerard Depardieu, globally on May 5, and a new Japanese original series, “Hibana,” globally in June.Netflix also is working on “3%” in Brazil, “Suburra” in Italy, “Dark” in Germany, an as-yet-untitled period series in Spain, a second season of “Club de Cuervos” from Mexico and another Mexican original series starring Kate del Castillo called “Ingobernable.” Plus, it is producing a Japanese anime series, “Perfect Bones.”Netflix executives on Monday's conference call said that they had no interest in bidding on several movie studios reportedly in play, including Viacom (VIAB) subsidiary Paramount and Starz (STRZA).“It’s been 15 years we’ve been public and 20 years existing, and we’ve done no M&A,” Hastings said. “So I think that probably speaks for itself.”Netflix Chief Content Officer Ted Sarandos said Netflix is building its own production capabilities.Netflix has been successful growing its content production organically, so it doesn’t make sense to “juice it with M&A,” Hastings said.Netflix is considering allowing customers in some markets with poor Internet infrastructure to download shows and movies for offline viewing.“We’ve been so focused on click-and-watch and the beauty and simplicity of streaming,” Hastings said. “But as we expand around the world, where we see an uneven set of networks, it’s something we should keep an open mind about.”But Netflix executives scoffed at the idea of offering live sports. They also said that virtual reality programming was not something the company is considering.VR for the consumer market likely will be focused on video game experiences for the foreseeable future, Hastings said.At least 10 analysts cut their price targets on Netflix stock in response to the company’s Q1 report.Oppenheimer analyst Jason Helfstein lowered his price target on Netflix to 123 from 140 but reiterated his outperform rating on the stock.The company’s second-quarter guidance suggests slower-than-expected international subscriber growth, Helfstein said.“The magnitude of the global launch in Q1 (to 130 new countries) makes a hyperlocal content strategy impractical in the short term,” he said in a report. “As such, it appears near-term momentum will slow as Netflix decides which countries to focus on.”Pivotal Research Group analyst Jeffrey Wlodarczak cut his price target to 145 from 155 but kept his buy rating.Netflix’s Q2 international guidance was well below expectations, he said. Wall Street analysts on average were looking for 2.8 million new international subscribers, vs. the 2 million that Netflix forecast.“We had frankly anticipated more pent-up demand in these international markets (even with an initially less appealing focus on English-language programming and international payments), and now it appears that in these new markets Netflix will need to first invest in new localized content/improved payment mechanisms to accelerate growth, which will take time,” Wlodarczak said in a report.FBR analyst Barton Crockett raised his price target to 104 from 100 and maintained his market perform rating. But he called the company’s international subscriber guidance “jarring.”

Sumner Redstone won his fight to be rid of a former girlfriend, as a Los Angeles probate judge threw out her lawsuit alleging the 92-year-old media billionaire was mentally incompetent.The ruling ends the case on the second day of a trial but may not avoid a further public airing of the infighting among the Redstone family, some of his former girlfriends, and the nurses who take care of the former Viacom (VIAB) and CBS (CBS) chairman. Within minutes of Monday’s ruling, Redstone’s former lover sued Redstone’s daughter Shari, her two sons and members of his household staff over claims they interfered with her expected inheritance.The trial opened Friday with Redstone’s videotaped testimony in which he used expletives to describe his ex-girlfriend, Manuela Herzer, and said he wanted her out of his life. While the recording confirmed Redstone was in frail health and required help speaking, his wish for Herzer to have no role in his health care decisions was clear.“Redstone’s testimony has ultimately defeated her case,” Los Angeles Superior Court Judge David Cowan said Monday in his ruling. “Though Herzer may have believed that Redstone would not be able to say anything, or be able to understand the questions, he did both.”Cowan said there were no legal grounds for him “not to follow his stated wishes.”Herzer made her next step in the fight clear with her new lawsuit in Los Angeles state court. Sumner Redstone cut Herzer out of his will last year when he also removed her as his health care agent, the person to make decisions for him when he is no longer able. Herzer seeks at least $70 million in her lawsuit.The abrupt end of the trial lessens the chance that trustees of Redstone’s estate will step in for the time being. He owns majority voting rights through National Amusements Inc. and, were he declared incompetent by the judge, that could have set in motion a chain of events that would shift control of that company to seven trustees, among them Shari Redstone and Viacom Chief Executive Officer Philippe Dauman.“Ms. Herzer bet wrong when she assumed that Mr. Redstone’s difficulty communicating would result in her reinstatement in his life and fortune,” Robert N. Klieger, one of Redstone’s lawyers, said in a statement.Redstone will seek to recover money that he lavished on Herzer and another ex-girlfriend, Klieger said. “Mr. Redstone is looking forward to liberating the $150 million in ‘gifts’ to Ms. Herzer and her friend,” he said.Pierce O’Donnell, Herzer’s lawyer, said he will appeal Monday’s decision.Herzer filed a petition in November to have Redstone declared incompetent and have her reinstated as his health care proxy. Redstone’s lawyers accused her of being more concerned about being removed from his will, which would have left her $50 million and his Los Angeles mansion in the Beverly Park neighborhood valued at $20 million.Herzer, who describes herself as Redstone’s longtime friend, companion and caretaker, had lived with him since April 2013, together with then-girlfriend Sydney Holland. Herzer dated Redstone from 1999 to 2001, according to her petition. Redstone’s mental health declined rapidly after he broke off with Holland in August, according to Herzer.Trial witnesses would have included Dauman, who was named Redstone’s health care agent in October, and Shari Redstone, with whom the media mogul has had a rocky relationship. This year, she replaced Dauman as her father’s health care agent.Herzer claimed Redstone was being manipulated by the people around him when he kicked her out and that he had become a prisoner in his own home. She said Redstone had become a “living ghost.”Shari Redstone countered that her father’s health has improved since Herzer was out of his life. Keryn Redstone, the daughter of Redstone’s estranged son Brent, joined in the case to support Herzer, arguing that the “tempestuous and difficult” relationship between her grandfather and her aunt necessitated that he be put under court protection.“I am grateful to the court for putting an end to this long ordeal‎,” Shari Redstone said in a statement. “I am so happy for my father that he can now live his life in peace, surrounded by his friends and family."

Disney (DIS) is helping fund digital publishing platform Playbuzz, just months after Disney put another $200 million into millennial-focused outlet Vice Media.New York-based Playbuzz said Thursday that it had raised $15 million in new funding led by Saban Ventures, an affiliate of the investment firm Saban Capital Group, which specializes in entertainment, media and communications.Playbuzz, which has existing partnerships with Mashable, USA Today, Viacom’s (VIAB) MTV and thousands of other digital publishers, offers slideshows, quizzes and other Internet-friendly content. The platform says that it has more than a billion users across its network and is accessed by more than 200 countries and territories in more than 40 languages.Saban and Disney mostly contributed the $15 million, according to the Wall Street Journal, citing sources familiar with the matter.The move comes as traditional media outlets fight to compete with quick online reads and entertainment companies contend with the likes of Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN). Such viewer trends have drawn scrutiny to Disney and others as investors and analysts keep a close eye on paid subscription figures.Comcast’s (CMCSA) NBCUniversal has previously invested in Re/code parent Vox Media and popular news and entertainment site BuzzFeed.Disney shares closed up 0.4%. Viacom rose 2.9%, Netflix ended virtually flat, Amazon lost 0.8%, and Comcast rose 0.5%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Meanwhile, Viacom posted first-quarter per-share earnings that fell 8.5% to $1.18, in line with estimates, as revenue dipped 6% to $3.15 billion, missing analysts' views for $3.26…

Even as media stocks short-circuit this week as subscribers trickle from cable to Netflix (NFLX), one company that many wrote off as a relic of Saturday mornings and Monday nights in prior decades has actually added paid subscribers.That would be World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE), which years ago launched a thousand elbow drops from recliners in kids' living rooms and just as many arguments over the campus-lounge TV between "Monday Night Raw" fans and, well, everyone else.However, WWE stock fell 4.8% to close at 19.79 on the stock market today, dropping along with other media stocks. The stock is above its 200-day moving average after undercutting that key level intraday.WWE on Thursday said its first-quarter earnings per share fell 55% to 8 cents, missing estimates for 10 cents. Revenue rose 10% to $188.4 million, beating expectations for $183.71 million.But WWE also said that the WWE Network, its online streaming service, averaged 1.49 million paid subscribers in the first quarter, a 16% jump from a year ago and slightly above the company's outlook for 1.48 million.WWE had faced concerns that it no longer had iconic stars.WWE also raised the low end of its second-quarter forecast range of average paid subscribers to "at least" 1.63 million, based on the viewers following WrestleMania 33, which took place in Orlando and was broadcast on April 2.The results indicate that a strategy that raised concerns among many in the financial world was starting to work.WWE launched the streaming service a little more than three years ago and now offers a free month's worth of programming upon signing up. WrestleMania 33 — the event during which many of the previous months' storylines reach their denouements — was also offered for free.At WrestleMania 33, the Undertaker retired after nearly 30 years with WWE. Donald Trump, who a decade ago helped shave CEO Vince McMahon's head in the ring, is in the WWE Hall of Fame.The company said WrestleMania made up nearly 30% of all "social TV interactions" on April 2, more than the season finale of AMC's "The Walking Dead," the Country Music Awards or Major League Baseball's opening day, which aired on Disney's (DIS) ESPN, which has been struggling to retain its huge subscriber base.WWE Network costs $9.99 a month. Management has said that around 1.3 million to 1.4 million subscribers would need to sign on for it to break even, Bloomberg noted last month.UBS, in a research note on Thursday, said that pay TV net subscriber additions had missed expectations by around 400,000. That note also said Turner Broadcasting indicated that "the national TV ad market softened up into 2017."Pay TV subscriber declines "appear to have accelerated markedly" in Q1, the note said, possibly due in part to recent price hikes on traditional services.RELATED:Media Giants Dive On Ad Woes; Hulu Debuts Live-TV Service

X Walt Disney (DIS) had been in buy range, but the stock is breaching a key level ahead of its quarterly results next week. The action comes as Time Warner (TWX) reported weak advertising revenue for the first quarter, sparking fears across the industry.Disney sank 2.4% on the stock market today. Viacom (VIAB) and CBS (CBS), which issue results Thursday, skidded 7.5% and 3.35%, respectively. Fox (FOXA) also got hit, off 5.1%. Fox issues its results along with Disney next week. Despite a major earnings topper, Viacom (VIAB) stock fell as much as 11% Thursday amid concerns that its flagship channels are losing ground in distribution.The MTV parent's chief executive said Viacom properties that appear on Charter Communications (CHTR) are now only on the cable giant's priciest cable-bundle tier, but Bob Bakish assured analysts that it was "not a broad re-tiering," according to Bloomberg.Viacom shares ended the trading day down 7.7% to 37.85 on the stock market today, recovering from a low of 35.20 but extending the stock's two-day dive, which was sparked Wednesday by Time Warner's (TWX) soft subscriber numbers and advertising revenue.The HBO parent, which is being bought by AT&T (T), dipped 0.8% to 98.30 Thursday. Disney (DIS) ticked down 0.6% to 111.17 after losing 2.4% Wednesday, undercutting its 50-day line and a buy point. CBS (CBS), which reports late today, rose 0.6% to 63.85 after dropping 3.35% yesterday, and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) added 0.6% to 29.04 after tumbling 5.1%.Viacom's flagship channels, which also include Comedy Central, Spike, VH1, BET and Nickelodeon, aren't found on too many skinny bundles either, as online players rush to build out over-the-top package services.Sony's (SNE) PlayStation Vue stopped carrying Viacom-owned channels last November, because it was "the best way for us to continue to offer the most compelling value to our fans." Hulu's newly announced live-TV bundle does not include Viacom's stations in its 50 or so available channels.Comedy Central is part of the core packages on Dish Network's (DISH) Sling TV, but MTV and Spike cost an extra $5 a month.For the quarter, Viacom's adjusted diluted earnings grew 4% to 79 cents a share, crushing views for 59 cents. Revenue growth of 8.5%, to $3.26 billion, exceeded estimates for $3.02 billion, on strength in Viacom's filmed-entertainment and media-networks segments.Media-networks revenue rose 1%, including a 2% decline in domestic revenue and a 11% bump in international revenue.Viacom' s filmed-entertainment segment, which includes Paramount Pictures, drew in $895 million, above estimates, as "xXx: Return of Xander Cage" helped the studio nearly double its theatrical revenue abroad.RELATED:Dow's Disney Is Breaching This Key Level Before Earnings Next Week: Warning Sign?Media Giants Dive On Ad Woes; Hulu Debuts Live-TV ServiceBig Media Stocks Unfazed Even As Hollywood Came To Brink Of Stoppage

Solid jobs growth showed the economy is on track, keeping the Federal Reserve on course as well.The Nasdaq rose nearly 1% for the week while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 index advanced modestly, despite some big headwinds. Apple, a Dow component, along with Facebook and especially Tesla, pulled back following quarterly reports. Crude oil futures tumbled to their lowest levels since November, dragging down energy stocks. Fiber optic stocks warned of sluggish China demand, but cited booming growth in the U.S.Consumer electronics giant Apple (AAPL) earned $2.10 a share, up 11% year over year, on revenue of $52.9 billion, up 5%, in the March fiscal second quarter. It's business as usual on Wall Street, with big media stocks unfazed Tuesday, but writers and studios narrowly came to a contract agreement in the wee hours, preventing a major work stoppage in Hollywood that would've impacted the industry that Walt Disney (DIS), CBS (CBS) and others call home.Both sides came to a truce shortly after midnight, when the current contract expired, reported Variety.According to a statement posted on the Writers Guild of America site, negotiators were "pleased to report that we have reached a tentative agreement with the AMPTP that we can recommend for ratification."Disney shares dipped 0.3% in the stock market today. CBS sank 1.5%. 21st Century Fox (FOXA) rose 0.1%. Viacom (VIAB) fell 0.3%.Among the gains were health plan contributions "that should ensure its solvency for years to come," and job protection for parental leave, it said. Pay-TV residuals were bumped up by 15% and options and exclusivity protections were expanded.The agreement, according to the memo, also help put to bed an issue spurred by the trend toward shorter seasons, such as those favored by Netflix (NFLX): now, episodic fees are worth 2.4 weeks of work, and overtime must be paid. A key TV writers' complaint going into the talks was that shorter seasons translated to less pay for the same amount of work, since Guild members are paid per episode.The last strike, which lasted 100 days in 2007 through early 2008, punished the industry to the tune of $2.1 billion, according to the Milken Institute.This time around, the addition of Netflix and Amazon (AMZN) to the mix means that a work stoppage could have accelerated a shift to digital platforms, said Barclays analysts last month."While Netflix and Amazon's pipelines are also likely to be affected by the writers' strike, their library of original content could realize much wider viewership in the absence of competition from legacy TV," wrote Barclays analysts Ross Sandler and Kannan Venkateshwar on April 12. "These companies also have the ability to source content globally, as evidenced by the number of British shows on Netflix."Netflix edged up 0.&% while Amazon dipped 0.1% after both surged to record highs on Monday.Moody's said Monday that a strike would have weighed on media companies that need studio content to survive."Most at risk if there is a protracted strike would be movie theater companies, followed by broadcast television networks and premium pay-TV channels, especially companies that are highly leveraged or weakly positioned relative to their existing credit ratings," said Moody's Senior Vice President Neil Begley in a Monday note."Least at risk would be major studios and broadcasters that are well-diversified and have relatively strong balance sheets."RELATED:Who Is Most At Risk If Hollywood's Writers Strike Tuesday?Why Netflix, Facebook, Amazon Could Flourish If Hollywood's Writers Strike

Watching a movie in 10-second snippets over the course of five days might sound maddening.But the 110 million cumulative views on Snapchat for teen thriller "Sickhouse" say otherwise. The numbers reinforce views that an audience exists for narrative content on nontraditional sites. And they suggest entertainment industry competition will continue to ratchet higher, with social media competing directly with television and streaming platforms for viewers.XWriters are poised to go on strike as they duke it out with studios over the sweeping changes to the industry wrought by Netflix (NFLX), Hulu and Amazon (AMZN) Video. But the next frontier already is at the door, thanks to moves by Snap's (SNAP) Snapchat and perhaps, soon enough, Facebook (FB).For now, traditional Hollywood studios are eager to team up with streaming video newcomers in a bid for coveted Gen Z and millennial viewers."The team at Snap is thinking about mobile TV differently than anyone else in this space," said Barry Poznick, president of Unscripted Television MGM, in a March announcement on a partnership between MGM Television and Snap.The shared goal is to develop and produce "TV-like mobile video content" for Snapchat's Discover feature. "We are excited to create content for their vast and hard-to-reach audience that consumes entertainment in a very specific fashion," Poznick added.The uniquely formatted "Sickhouse" — essentially "Blair Witch Project" for the internet age — was shot on just two Apple (AAPL) iPhones and rolled out in nearly 500 successive Snaps last year through the account of popular Snapchatter Andrea Russett. It wasn't a production backed by Snap, but has been billed broadly as the messaging app's first full-length movie.Indigenous Media produced the project and has since repackaged it in a standard format. COO Jake Avnet is more than pleased with the release of the full version of "Sickhouse," which has been fleshed out to 68 minutes. A sequel is in the works.He won't say how much the first film has made so far, but it has "performed well on virtually every platform (on which) it's been made available." The film is available on AT&T (T)-backed Fullscreen and can be purchased for $5.99 on iTunes, Vimeo and Amazon Video."We've been happy to see there's been a very healthy, sort of, second life to the film beyond that first Snapchat window," he said.The indie flick was no doubt unconventional in production, format and distribution. But as Twitter bloomed with discussion over whether Andrea Russett's increasingly creepy Snapchat activity was real or staged, the five-day social media debate perhaps indicates that young people's attention spans aren't gnatlike after at all, if the content is juicy enough to follow."Sickhouse" director Hannah Macpherson should know. She also writes and directs "[email protected]," an AwesomenessTV-produced series available through Verizon Communications' (VZ) Go90 app. A "modern-day thriller that explores the terrifying risks of social media in a world of anonymity," the show's second season is about to begin."That's a show that streams on teenagers' phones," she told Investor's Business Daily. "So I'm very familiar that that's how teenagers are watching a lot of content. They're not watching just two-minute YouTube clips. They're watching 10 hours of 'House of Cards' on their cellphones."Not surprisingly, traditional entertainment giants like Disney (DIS) and Viacom (VIAB) see an opportunity. Comcast (CMCSA) unit NBCUniversal even invested $500 million in Snap's initial public offering.As they scramble to be where younger eyeballs are, they've put their content on Snapchat, which features videos from ESPN, Comedy Central and the Wall Street Journal. Offerings also include ABC's "Watch Party: The Bachelor," BBC's "Planet Earth II" and original shorts from NBC's "Saturday Night Live."Snap's fresh slate of programming has a decidedly "Real World"-era MTV feel to it. There's A&E's "Second Chance" (exes meet to dissect their broken relationships) and the soon-to-debut Vice Media's "Hungry Hearts with Action Bronson" (the rapper/chef plays matchmaker).Then there's Snap's in-house production, "Good Luck America," which is in its second season and attempts to make politics accessible for its viewers, Rock the Vote-style.Other social media heavyweights have their own plans in motion. Twitter (TWTR), for its part, has so far kept its video focus on sports and news. On top of partnerships with CBS (CBS) News, Bloomberg, Major League Baseball, the National Basketball Association and others, the company intends to stream 1,500 hours of e-sports on the platform this year.Facebook's TV guide is fuzzier, as the social networking giant builds out a video hub for all kinds of viewable content.It has begun funding "seed video content" that includes "original and licensed scripted, unscripted and sports content that takes advantage of mobile and the social interaction unique to Facebook," the company's head of global creative strategy, Ricky Van Veen, told Recode in December.No specific show announcements have been made, but the Silicon Valley giant sounds like it's headed to Hollywood.In February, reports surfaced that Facebook had poached MTV's head of scripted development to become its head of development for original programming. Not long after that, Wall Street Journal sources said the company was looking for up-to-30-minute "TV-like" originals that focus on science, pop culture, sports and more — a far cry from the site's typical user-generated Facebook Live videos or short viral clips. Recent Facebook job listings also point to its desire to develop media and entertainment liaisons in Los Angeles.Long term, whether studios and networks benefit from partnering with social media outlets "remains to be seen," said Morningstar tech analyst Ali Mogharabi.In Snapchat's case, content created for its nonstandard portrait-mode style renders it unusable on TV or even other online counterparts."I think in the short to medium term, some of those (companies) will realize that this may not have been a worthy investment," he said.But it might also be a necessary evil, given the sway Snapchat, Facebook and Twitter have, and the chance that they could lure more talent away from the entertainment industry. Sony Entertainment CEO Michael Lynton, an early Snap investor, announced in January that he would step down from the media conglomerate to focus on being Snap's chairman full-time."Facebook's got a lot of money and a lot of pulse on the core millennial class," Magid Advisors President Mike Vorhaus told Investor's Business Daily. "Snapchat's cool and edgy and all video all the time, and it's got a special kind of brand that you could've compared to brands like MTV 30, 40 years ago. So people are going to take a call from Snapchat, right? Joss Whedon gets a phone call (from) Snapchat — he's gonna take that."For social media networks, whose users generate a seemingly endless stream of free video content every day, there's the inevitable question of risk. Why take on the unwieldy task of funding and creating original programming? Everyone knows entertainment is a hit-or-miss industry, so why not beef up those video libraries by licensing other people's shows?"We think (Facebook is) basically trying to expand its ecosystem, which they're hoping (will) keep users in the net ecosystem for a longer time," Morningstar's Mogharabi said. "If they're successful at doing that, then they could attract some more ad dollars."Snap, on the other hand, is "pretty much doing the same thing for different reasons," he said. "These guys actually need to build user base to begin with."At this early stage, Mogharabi doesn't see Netflix-style ambitions in Snap's and Facebook's futures. But assuming that user growth and engagement follow, he says, Snap will be looking to rake in advertisers' money.A recent episode of E!'s "The Rundown," which totaled fewer than 20 Snaps, included three ads for "Fast and the Furious" sequel "The Fate of the Furious," which was slated to come out in theaters later that week.That could present a worry to entertainment executives courting advertising sales.Twitter recently announced plans to present for the first time at the Digital Content Newfronts in May. (The "newfronts" are an online-media counterpart to traditional upfronts, where media buyers make their ad-space purchases.) Without divulging much else, the company said it "will showcase new original content offerings and live programming to brands and agencies entering the 2017 upfront season."And last fall, eMarketer estimated that digital ad spending for 2016 would overtake TV ad spending for the first time. Its projections show a widening gap between digital and TV ad spending as the years go on.It's worth keeping in mind, however, that digital advertising growth "hasn't necessarily come at a cost to TV ad budget," said Morningstar's Mogharabi."TV ad dollars are still growing, of course at a much slower rate, but that's been the case for a while," he said. "It's not necessarily that every percentage growth that you see in digital ad dollars is actually coming from television.  ...  It's not a so-called binary case."That may give Hollywood — with its legacy entourage of agents, producers, directors and development execs — some comfort.And yet, while the big media companies aren't likely to quake in the face of Mark Zuckerberg's video tab or a few Venice Beach young guns with an app, they know better than to brush off competition from peculiar places.After all, with Amazon Studios' lauded "Manchester by the Sea," the same e-commerce company that sells Echos, diapers and books online now carries the sheen of the Academy Awards. (The film, which was nominated for Best Picture, landed a statuette for Original Screenplay; star Casey Affleck notched a win in the lead-actor category.)"I think (network execs) kind of get it in a way that they might not have gotten it four years ago or six years ago, depending on who you were talking about," Vorhaus said."So it's not, like, all of a sudden they're going to go, 'Oh my God, Snap and Facebook, they're surprising us just like — you know, some of us would admit — Netflix surprised us.' So I don't think the surprise is big. I think they get the frenemy concept."

Hoping to attract cable TV cord-cutters and cord-nevers, Sony (SNE) on Monday took its Internet-based PlayStation Vue service nationwide.Sony launched its live and on-demand TV service in March 2015 in test markets, including New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Philadelphia, Dallas, San Francisco and Miami.PlayStation Vue offers “skinny TV” bundles of channels starting at $29.99 a month, with no long-term contracts or hidden fees. It competes with a similar online service from Dish Network (DISH) called Sling TV.PlayStation Vue boasts that it offers the most popular channels, including AMC, CNN, Discovery, Disney and ESPN.However, content from ABC, FOX (FOX) and NBC is available for now only as on-demand content in Vue’s Slim multichannel plans. Most on-demand content will be available within 24 hours after broadcast. CBS (CBS) programming will be added later, Sony said in a press release.Sony Network Entertainment International (SNEI) said that it is working to add live local broadcast stations across all networks.Vue offers three service plans. Access Slim has over 55 channels and costs $29.99 a month; Core Slim has over 70 channels for $34.99 a month; and Elite Slim has over 100 channels for $44.99 a month.The Vue service is accessible through Sony’s PlayStation 3 and 4 game consoles, Amazon.com (AMZN) Fire TV and Fire TV Stick, as well as the Apple (AAPL) iPad and iPhone with the Vue mobile app.“Since launching a year ago, our priority with PlayStation Vue has been to secure the best TV content for our audience and make it available to consumers nationwide; today, we’re delivering on that promise,” Eric Lempel, senior vice president of marketing and head of SNEI’s PlayStation Network Americas, said in a statement. “PlayStation Vue has been an ambitious project from the start, and national expansion demonstrates our ability to innovate in an industry that’s overdue for a reinvented experience."Thanks to the strong network relationships we’ve forged and technology we’ve built, consumers nationwide can enjoy a better way to watch TV.”Sony PlayStation Vue has program deals with AMC Networks (AMCX), CBS, Discovery Communications (DISCA), Disney (DIS)/ABC Television Group, ESPN, Fox, NBCUniversal, Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI), Turner Broadcasting and Viacom (VIAB).Vue also offers customers a cloud-based DVR, which allows users to store thousands of hours of content with conflict-free recording.

Viacom (VIAB) said it is exploring the sale of a "significant strategic" minority stake in its film studio, Paramount Pictures, after possible investors expressed interest. But who might those future partners be?"We have received indications of interest from potential partners seeking a strategic investment in Paramount Pictures and I have decided to pursue discussions with a select group of potential investors," said Viacom CEO Philippe Dauman in a Tuesday statement. He announced the news at the Jefferies Media & Communications Conference in New York City.Viacom shares were briefly halted and rose as high as 39.45 intraday, but in closed up just 0.4% at 37.01 on the stock market today.Dauman, who recently took the reins from Sumner Redstone as executive chairman, said in the company's Feb. 9 earnings release that 2015 was a "challenging year" as Viacom redesigned itself and adapted to "significant industry disruption." Revenue missed estimates, though earnings matched views. Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN), among other over-the-top services, have been shaking up entertainment consumption for several years now.Don't expect the new interest in an equity stake to come from anyone else in Hollywood, says one analyst."We would expect minority partners to likely be from China, given that country's global box office ambitions and possibly as well as from India (Reliance)," said wrote Stifel analyst Benjamin Mogil. "We would not expect any domestic or European suitors."Such a development would be favorable, he said, "given that Paramount, from a replacement value, could be worth north of $10 (billion), in our view, compared to the current Viacom enterprise value of $28 (billion)."Other traditional media companies, including Walt Disney (DIS), Time Warner (TWX), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and others, have had to adapt to the modern viewer. Uncertainty in the industry has weighed on media stocks.Netflix fell 3.1% and Amazon 1.2%. Walt Disney fell 1% and 21st Century Fox 1.5%, while Time Warner advanced 0.6%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Walt Disney’s (DIS) first-quarter results trounced expectations as “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” boosted the studio and consumer products segments, though the media and entertainment giant continued to lose subscribers for its cable channels.But Disney CEO Robert Iger said Tuesday that ESPN, which lost 7 million subscribers in the last two years, has “actually seen an uptick” in subscribers in recent months, and has benefited from the growth of light cable packages, particularly from Dish (DISH).In what amounted to a vigorous defense of ESPN during a conference call, Iger said skinny bundles with the sports cable channel had even wooed cord cutters back. The idea that ESPN is cratering is “ridiculous,” he said. “Sports is too popular.”Disney shares fell 3% late.Iger also clarified the reason behind ESPN’s subscriber decline, blaming faulty Nielsen figures. Once Nielsen corrected those numbers, “we concluded that our sub loss was largely due to the fact that ESPN was not part of skinny bundles that had launched,” he said.He said Disney is exploring “new platform providers,” hinting at more over-the-top, or streaming, options for ESPN.Revenue from Disney’s media networks division, which includes ESPN, grew 8% in fiscal Q1. The segment logged higher ad revenue, offset by lower ratings. Higher programming costs weighed on the sports cable channel, due to the timing of the College Football Playoff bowl games, but that was partially offset by an increase in ad and affiliate revenue, said the company."Affiliate revenue growth was due to contractual rate increases, partially offset by a decline in subscribers and unfavorable foreign currency translation impacts," Disney said in a statement.The hubbub over ESPN comes amid industry-wide concerns that cable viewers are taking their dollars elsewhere — namely, to Netflix (NFLX), Amazon (AMZN) Prime and other over-the-top streaming services.During the quarter, adjusted earnings climbed 28% to $1.63 a share, well above views for $1.45 per share. Revenue grew 14% to $15.24 billion vs. consensus estimates for $14.75 billion.“Driven by the phenomenal success of ‘Star Wars,’ we delivered the highest quarterly earnings in the history of our company, marking our 10th consecutive quarter of double-digit EPS growth,” said Iger in a statement.“The Force Awakens” crossed the $2 billion threshold in global box office sales over the weekend. Studio revenue skyrocketed 46%, year over year.Disney’s theme park and resorts segment revenue rose 9%, said the company. Consumer products and interactive media revenue rose 8%.Earlier Tuesday, Viacom (VIAB) shares tanked 21.5% after the media company logged its fourth consecutive quarter of revenue declines and Q1 revenue fell short of expectations.Earnings fell 8.5% to $1.18, in line with consensus estimates, as sales fell 6% to $3.15 billion, below analysts’ forecasts for $3.26 billion.Viacom's filmed entertainment revenue tumbled 15% on theatrical and home-entertainment revenue declines. Media-networks revenue fell 3% as domestic ad revenue dropped 4% and ratings declined.

Internet television network Netflix (NFLX) is a clear winner in the over-the-top video market, but its stock is fully valued at current levels, Rosenblatt Securities said Tuesday.Rosenblatt analyst Alan Gould initiated coverage of Netflix stock at neutral with a price target of 150.Netflix was down 1% to 145.50 at the close on the stock market today. It hit a record high of 148.29 on Thursday."Netflix has greatly accelerated the change in TV consumer behavior," Gould said in a report. "However, as much as we admire the company's strategy and execution, we feel the stock is appropriately valued at close to $150 per share based on our sum-of-the-parts analysis."Gould also initiated coverage of six other media stocks. He gave buy ratings to CBS (CBS) and Lions Gate Entertainment (LGFA). He rated Walt Disney (DIS), Twenty-First Century Fox (FOX), Time Warner (TWX) and Viacom (VIAB) as neutral.He set a price target of 80 on CBS and 32 on Lions Gate.CBS added 0.5% to 69.20, and Lions Gate was down a fraction to 26.31.As for Netflix, Gould sees the company exceeding 240 million global subscribers by 2025, resulting in more than $40 billion in revenue and $12 in earnings per share.IBD'S TAKE: Netflix is one of four closely watched internet stocks that make up the FANG group. The others are Facebook, Amazon.com and Google-parent Alphabet. For the latest news on the group, visit IBD's FANG stocks page.Netflix ended 2016 with 93.8 million streaming subscribers worldwide. It earned 43 cents a share on revenue of $8.83 billion for the year."Netflix is building a content moat and amortizing it over a global direct-to-consumer audience," Gould said. "It has the largest global subscriber base allowing it to be the lowest-cost provider on a per-subscriber basis. Furthermore, it has minimal distribution costs, and as Netflix produces more of its own content it becomes the producer, distributor and retailer allowing it to maximize profit."He projects that Netflix will be spending $15 billion a year on content in five years and $25 billion annually in 10 years.RELATED:Netflix Gets Caution Flag Ahead Of First-Quarter EarningsWill Video Kill The iPhone Star? Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN) are transforming Hollywood with apparent clarity about what they want: original content, a solid library and paying viewers.But does Big Media, rooted in almost-quaint traditions like upfronts and Nielsen ratings, know how to fight back in this brave new world of cord cutting? Or will the entertainment industry's center of gravity shift permanently to Silicon Valley?The threat of over-the-top (OTT) streaming services keeps raising the stakes for the incumbents, whose varied responses face a daunting task. Channels once deemed impervious are now bleeding subscribers, advertising dollars are getting plowed into digital media, and the disruptors are piling up awards.The trends are once again expected to be scrutinized as media giants report quarterly results in the coming week.Millennials and teens largely consider televisions to be old-school technology. Most 18- to 34-year-olds prefer watching shows on a laptop or mobile device, not a TV, according to a Magid Advisors poll.Major networks have followed young eyeballs over to the web. A hodgepodge of streaming services are available to viewers, ranging from multi-network Hulu to NBC's new comedy-centric outlet, SeeSo.More than 30 new OTT services were introduced in 2015 alone, said research firm SNL Kagan, which tracks over 100 such offerings. The overwhelming number of options might make it seem like traditional media outlets are having a hard time refining their strategies."I don’t think they’re hyper-focused; I don’t think they’re being sloppy," SNL Kagan analyst Ali Choukeir told Investor's Business Daily.But at the same time, there are so many different kinds of online streaming choices out there that it's "like spinning plates," he added. "There’s just a lot going on."NBCUniversal parent Comcast (CMCSA) has Stream for Internet-only customers. Walt Disney (DIS) launched OTT services abroad. Viacom (VIAB) introduced Noggin for kids.TBS and CNN parent Time Warner (TWX) allows users to watch its content from any device. It also offers premium cable network HBO in two streaming forms, HBO Now and HBO Go, the former being a standalone service available to non-cable subscribers.Time Warner is also said to be in talks to acquire a 25% equity stake in Hulu, the online streamer jointly owned by 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Disney and Comcast's NBCUniversal.Wall Street is increasingly paying attention to the paid subscription service with Big Media backing. Once dismissed as "Clown Co.," Hulu is now nothing to laugh at.The service has emerged as a viable OTT competitor to Netflix, Amazon and others, wrote Jefferies analyst John Janedis in a note to clients, highlighting its investment in content and new $11.99 ad-free subscription tier."We think Hulu is 'the OTT service to watch in 2016,'" he wrote last month, "as the impact of these changes starts to unfold, not only to the extent that it may slow Netflix’s subscriber growth, but also if the value proposition accelerates cord cutting of traditional linear television."Hulu has only 9 million subscribers to Netflix's nearly 45 million video customers in the U.S. (and over 75 million subscribers worldwide). But its growth rate outpaces that of Netflix and its broadcast parentage affords a unique feature: the ability to offer shows that have just aired on linear TV."With all these guys, especially Netflix and Amazon, they’ve all got original content," said Choukeir. "Original content is a differentiator for sure, but with Hulu, next-day (content) is a further differentiator."Potential investor Time Warner reportedly is not a fan of the feature, but Choukeir said he doesn't see the core of Hulu's business changing.If Time Warner comes on board, that'll leave CBS (CBS) as the only major network not on the service.But it may be happy to be left alone as it focuses on its streaming service CBS All Access, which offers both a live CBS feed and previously aired content, and mulls a possible streaming subscription service for the CW network, which it co-owns with Time Warner's Warner Bros.So how are Hulu, HBO and the rest of the field faring against digital pure plays?There are no clear winners or losers just yet, said SNL Kagan's Choukeir."There’s still a lot to be learned," he said. "There’s a lot of experimentation going on."Strategies may also evolve as media giants find their footing online. Netflix is a double-edged sword for them: Licensing revenue they receive is an appealing source of cash, but giving Netflix access to content is essentially feeding the competition.Time Warner and Fox executives have in recent months raised concerns about the issue, with Fox CEO James Murdoch reportedly saying the company might license more of its programming to Hulu instead.Advertising dollars are at risk, as marketers take their money to digital platforms at the expense of TV. Cowen & Co. believes that "digital is likely to take several hundred basis points of ad share away from national TV in 2016 and 2017."Additionally, one area that has long been considered a pay-TV stronghold -- live sports -- faces uncertainty. Disney's longtime moneymaker, ESPN, lost 7 million subscribers between 2013-15, bringing its total to 92 million as of late last year.Concern over subscriber losses and cord-cutting prompted a media meltdown last August. Cowen analyst Doug Creutz noted that media stocks should get "a bit of a reprieve" in the first half of 2016 as ad trends have improved, cord-cutting doesn't appear to be accelerating, and the group is trading at a discount to the market.But he also said the major media names "remain difficult as longer-term investments."When it comes to online efforts, it may simply be a matter of kicking back on the sofa and watching which streaming subscription services find fame and fortune -- and which get voted off the island."It’s tough to forecast when we’re going to see a shakeout, because the marketplace is very saturated." said Choukeir. "But at the same time, there are a lot of services out there catering to audiences who are buying their content."

Thanks to Netflix, Twitter and a seemingly bottomless well of material to rehash, the movie business has fundamentally transformed into a go-big-or-go-home arena — and chances are, it won't ever change back.

Out of the 691 titles released theatrically last year, just two brought in over 10% of domestic grosses, and they weren't based on new material, but on sequels to a 23-year-old dinosaur adventure and a space epic from the late '70s.

"Between 'Jurassic World' and 'Star Wars' alone, in 2015, they made over $1.2 billion," said Rentrak (RENT) box office analyst Paul Dergarabedian. "You're talking about two movies making over a billion. Two."

The lopsided box-office takes for "Jurassic World" and "Star Wars" were not for lack of new releases. The major studios, including Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Viacom's (VIAB) Paramount, Comcast's (CMCSA) Universal and Time Warner's (TWX) Warner Bros., collectively put out 86 movies last year, up 16% from 2014's 74 releases, according to Exhibitor Relations data.
And 2015 proved to be a banner year in film: Ticket sales in the U.S. and Canada climbed 7.4% to hit a record $11.1 billion.
But not all movies are created equal. The top-20 grossing movies carried 50% of last year's box office, up from 41% in 2014 and 42% in 2013, as Hollywood shifts its development strategy.
"You're sort of seeing a bifurcation of what studios are really looking to invest in," Morningstar analyst Neil Macker told IBD.

Studios are migrating to a "barbell strategy," he said, developing more high-budget, blockbuster-type movies, as well as more lower-budget films that don't require crushed box-office records to prove profitable. That means mid-budget movies — often rom-coms and talky dramas — get left by the wayside.

This is partly a reflection of viewer trends. The average moviegoer has become more discriminating, said Stifel analyst Benjamin Mogil, as online streaming-video options like Netflix (NFLX) or Apple (AAPL) iTunes movie rentals gain steam.
Also not helping movies is the "explosion of prestige drama" on TV, as Macker puts it, from networks like Time Warner's HBO, Fox's FX, Netflix and Amazon (AMZN) Video.
"That's where a lot of the (screen)writers are going and a lot of the viewers are going also," he said.

So when consumers do plan on a Friday night at the movies, they want the "full theatrical experience," Mogil told IBD. And surround sound and big screens merit explosions, special effects and pop culture fanfare.
Last year "clearly marked one where dramas and comedies, along with many kids films and horror, had challenges," he wrote separately in a Jan. 3 note.

"While ticket prices have largely remained in check of late, the increased proliferation/ease of (video on demand) and (subscription video on demand) have made the theater-going experience one which outperforms for the major event titles but has difficulty for middle-of-the-road fare."
Even Apple Flops In Theaters

That might explain why "Steve Jobs," the biopic on the Apple co-founder, took in less than $18 million, despite being penned by Aaron Sorkin and starring heavy hitters like Kate Winslet and Michael Fassbender.
Meanwhile, 2015 box office winner "The Force Awakens" has raked in more money than all eight Oscar-nominated best picture contenders combined, both domestically and abroad.

Action-heavy spectacles appear to translate across cultures better than other films. Universal's "Furious 7" — the seventh installment of "The Fast and the Furious" franchise — is the No. 6 grossing film of all time, according to Box Office Mojo.

But that's not to say that simply making any old blockbuster or sequel will do. Plenty have bombed. "Fantastic Four," which had a reported $120 million production budget, brought in only $56.1 million domestically last year.
The Twitter Effect

This broad shift in cinema trends has contributed to a repetitive theatrical cycle of "Groundhog Day" proportions, with more franchise-based blockbusters, more people watching those blockbusters, and more studios making blockbusters because that appears to be what's working.
Only two of the top-grossing 2015 releases were originals: Disney Pixar's "Inside Out" and Twentieth Century Fox's "The Martian."
"Hollywood has always had the attitude of: If something succeeds, do it again and again and again until people get sick of it," said Exhibitor Relations analyst Karie Bible.

Online chatter can also add to the snowball effect that nudges people toward already-popular tentpole titles instead of smaller critical darlings, widening the chasm between blockbusters and average performers, as well as shrinking the margin of error for studios.

"Often when studios try to get very creative or original ... the audience just stays away," Dergarabedian said. "It just depends on the movie and the buzz. All the marketing dollars in the world can't change the social media sentiment, and that's the thing the studios can't control."
Mogil echoed the idea that the Twitter (TWTR)-verse has sway as a collective culture influencer.
"Because of social media, people know really quickly if it's a good movie or not," he said.

In 2016, more sequels and reboots are expected to lead the box office again. Stifel predicts that March's release of "Batman v. Superman" and December's "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story" will each make about $400 million apiece. "The Force Awakens," which came out in mid-December, is expected to deliver another $300 million this year for Disney.
'Fast and the Furious 27'?

If viewers' habits line up with all of Stifel's top-10 predictions, that will mean that all but one film — Disney's new animated princess, "Moana" — will be spinoffs or sequels to existing properties, such as "Harry Potter," "Star Trek," "Independence Day" and "Alice in Wonderland."
Will moviegoers ever weary of superhero sequels and epic franchises?

"It's a tougher question because you need a bunch of sequels to bomb out before you decide not to make them," said Mogil. "And if they work abroad, you're still going to be making them. There will always be breakout hits from (intellectual property) that are brand new. Universal's "Furious 7" — the seventh installment of "The Fast and the Furious" franchise — is the No. 6 grossing film of all time, according to Box Office Mojo.But that's not to say that simply making any old blockbuster or sequel will do. Plenty have bombed. "Fantastic Four," which had a reported $120 million production budget, brought in only $56.1 million domestically last year.The Twitter EffectThis broad shift in cinema trends has contributed to a repetitive theatrical cycle of "Groundhog Day" proportions, with more franchise-based blockbusters, more people watching those blockbusters, and more studios making blockbusters because that appears to be what's working.Only two of the top-grossing 2015 releases were originals: Disney Pixar's "Inside Out" and Twentieth Century Fox's "The Martian.""Hollywood has always had the attitude of: If something succeeds, do it again and again and again until people get sick of it," said Exhibitor Relations analyst Karie Bible.Online chatter can also add to the snowball effect that nudges people toward already-popular tentpole titles instead of smaller critical darlings, widening the chasm between blockbusters and average performers, as well as shrinking the margin of error for studios."Often when studios try to get very creative or original ... the audience just stays away," Dergarabedian said. "It just depends on the movie and the buzz. All the marketing dollars in the world can't change the social media sentiment, and that's the thing the studios can't control."Mogil echoed the idea that the Twitter (TWTR)-verse has sway as a collective culture influencer."Because of social media, people know really quickly if it's a good movie or not," he said.In 2016, more sequels and reboots are expected to lead the box office again. Stifel predicts that March's release of "Batman v. Superman" and December's "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story" will each make about $400 million apiece. "The Force Awakens," which came out in mid-December, is expected to deliver another $300 million this year for Disney.'Fast and the Furious 27'?If viewers' habits line up with all of Stifel's top-10 predictions, that will mean that all but one film — Disney's new animated princess, "Moana" — will be spinoffs or sequels to existing properties, such as "Harry Potter," "Star Trek," "Independence Day" and "Alice in Wonderland."Will moviegoers ever weary of superhero sequels and epic franchises?"It's a tougher question because you need a bunch of sequels to bomb out before you decide not to make them," said Mogil. "And if they work abroad, you're still going to be making them. There will always be breakout hits from (intellectual property) that are brand new. (But) for the foreseeable future, (the industry will) go with stuff that works and stuff that's known."

The end of last year brought a host of predictions about how Apple (AAPL) might spend its more than $200 billion in cash and investments. Currently the Cupertino, Calif.-based company is using its cash on hand for stock buybacks and dividends.But some on Wall Street are itching for Apple to pull off a big acquisition with its pile of dough. The latest speculation has Apple among those interested in buying TV and movie giant Time Warner (), which has a current market cap of about $57 billion.The biggest deal Apple has ever made was purchasing Beats Music and Beats Electronics for $3 billion in August 2014.A New York Post article on Tuesday suggested that Time Warner CEO Jeff Bewkes is open to the possibility of a sale of the company. Since then, Apple, AT&T (T) and 21st Century Fox ()have been rumored as potential buyers of the entertainment conglomerate.The Post report said Apple would be interested in Time Warner's assets to support the launch of a stand-alone streaming TV service. Time Warner owns CNN, HBO, TBS, TNT and other cable channels.Fortune writer Philip Elmer-DeWitt outlined the reasons for a deal in a column titled "Why Apple Should Buy Time Warner."Apple has been trying for years to assemble a "skinny bundle" of popular cable channels for an Internet TV service but without success. Buying Time Warner would give that to Apple in an instant, he said.But just because Apple has the cash doesn't mean they will spend it on a big acquisition. Apple has been loath to make large acquisitions for fear of harming its corporate culture. Apple likes to make small tuck-in acquisitions of companies with interesting technologies or talented engineers. It also has a reputation for wanting to build new products and services in house rather than acquire what someone else has developed.In a Dec. 10 [PAGE[research]] report, FBR analyst Daniel Ives put together a "Christmas M&A list" of deals that Apple might consider in 2016. He listed Adobe Systems (ADBE), Box (BOX), GoPro (GPRO) and Tesla Motors (TSLA)."Although we clearly can see Cupertino focusing on a number of skunkworks initiatives (e.g., Project Titan, virtual reality Faceshift, etc.) in 2016 and not pursuing major M&A prospects, with $200 billion of cash in the coffer (and growing), we can finally envision Apple making a larger acquisition, as the conditions are ripe for (CEO Tim) Cook to make a move," Ives said.Research firm CCS Insight predicted Nov. 20 that Apple might buy either Box or Dropbox in 2016 to extend its iCloud package of services into the enterprise market.On Dec. 31, Investors.com published a list of "The wildest tech M&A predictions for 2016." Among those predictions, the writers and editors of entertainment magazine Variety predicted that Apple will buy a movie studio in 2016 to support its goals for a subscription Internet video service.Variety listed Viacom (VIAB), Sony (SNE) and Time Warner's HBO as possible targets.

Pictures' "Godzilla," as China and Hollywood continue to deepen their relationship. According to Reuters, citing a source familiar with the matter, an agreement has been signed, with…

At the end of every year, business journalists and Wall Street analysts sit down and write up their boldest predictions for mergers and acquisitions in the coming year. And like the people shown riding hoverboards in YouTube videos, they're likely to fall on their butts.Tech M&A predictions are often wrong because they're born out of wishful thinking. They ignore market realities, CEO personalities and other factors that can make such deals tough to pull off.But they're fun to consider. So with that in mind, here's a roundup of the boldest predictions for tech company mergers and acquisitions in 2016.Apple Buys Tesla MotorsApple (AAPL) is rumored to be working on an electric car and it could "dramatically accelerate" those efforts if it bought Tesla Motors (TSLA), says Aaron Task, digital editor at Fortune magazine."With over $200 billion cash on hand, the iPhone maker has more than ample resources to absorb the purchase, especially now that some of the bloom has come off Tesla's once-rosy stock," Task wrote. "In addition to its automobile know-how, Apple gets access to Tesla's battery, which CEO Elon Musk claims can help change 'the entire energy infrastructure of the world.'"Plus, Musk would be a worthy heir to Apple co-founder Steve Jobs and would be ideally suited to be Apple's futurist, chief technologist and CEO-in-waiting, Task said.AT&T Buys YahooWeb giant Yahoo (YHOO) will be sold to telecom powerhouse AT&T (T), mirroring Verizon's (VZ) acquisition of AOL earlier in the year, predicts Chris Ciaccia, technology editor at TheStreet."Yahoo's purchase of BrightRoll could help AT&T with its reported streaming service, as it seeks to have ads inserted into it," Ciaccia wrote. "There are other players for Yahoo, like a media company or a private equity firm, but AT&T just makes too much sense to me."GoPro Sold To Larger Tech FirmWith GoPro's (GPRO) stock depressed, a larger technology firm is likely to sweep in and buy the maker of action cameras, according to Orange Peel Investments."With zero debt and $513 million in cash, the company has a clean slate for an LBO to come in, whisk them off their feet and take advantage of the company's ability to lever," the firm said in a post on Seeking Alpha. "The obvious acquiring party in this transaction would be a larger technology or electronics outfit, such as an Apple, Samsung or Microsoft (MSFT). They could use the company's brand in a way similar to how Apple is using Beats. They could continue to have the brand name separate from the core brand and then eventually vertically integrate the two companies for future projects."Comcast Will Try To Buy NetflixIn a prediction out of left field, Yahoo Tech editor Dan Tynan believes cable giant Comcast (CMCSA) will try to acquire Internet TV service Netflix (NFLX) or possibly vice versa."Whether or not you're a cord-cutter, streaming media is the future of entertainment — and nobody streams bigger than Netflix, which accounted for nearly 40% of all Internet traffic last year. Since Big Cable can't beat the streamers at this game, the only thing left is for it to join them by acquisition," Tynan wrote. "Comcast ($192 billion valuation) and Netflix ($42 billion) are the most logical candidates for an arranged marriage. While it stands to reason that the larger company will swallow the smaller one, it's not inconceivable that the reverse will happen — not unlike AOL's acquisition of Time Warner 15 years ago, but perhaps with better results."Apple Buys A Movie StudioVariety magazine's writers and editors are predicting a lot of M&A activity in Hollywood in 2016. Most notably, they think Apple will buy a movie studio to support its goals for a subscription Internet video service."With more than $200 billion in cash on hand, the Cupertino colossus is poised to rewrite the rules of the media game," the Variety staff wrote. "Viacom (VIAB) or HBO might seem the likeliest prey, but Sony (SNE) is a juicier target, given the mix of hardware and programming under its hood."Variety thinks Chinese Internet giant Alibaba Group (BABA) also is interested in buying a Hollywood player. Possible targets for Alibaba include Viacom, CBS (CBS), Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF) and DreamWorks Animation.However, John Malone is most likely to snap up Lions Gate and merge it with cable channel Starz (STRZA), Variety said.Time Warner (TWX), parent of HBO and Warner Bros., could become an M&A target in 2016, Variety said. One likely bidder would be 21st Century Fox (FOXA), the trade paper said.Intel Or Qualcomm Buys InvenSenseU.K.-based research firm CCS Insight makes a lot of annual tech industry predictions, including some about mergers and acquisitions.It predicts that Intel (INTC) or Qualcomm (QCOM) will acquire InvenSense (INVN) in 2016."The acquisition follows a large fall in the market capitalization of InvenSense in the second half of 2015," CCS Insight said in a report. "Its purchaser recognizes the opportunity to snap up InvenSense's assets in sensor technology. As sensors take on greater importance in the Internet of Things and wearable devices, the buyer integrates InvenSense's technology into a wider range of semiconductors."CCS Insight also predicts that Samsung will acquire chipmaker GlobalFoundries by 2017."GlobalFoundries is currently struggling to compete against Intel, Samsung and TSMC (TSM)," it said. "Chip manufacturing becomes increasingly capital- and scale-intensive, with huge pressure on capacity as demand balloons for silicon for the Internet of Things. Samsung's foundry business accounts for a growing proportion of the company's profit, and the acquisition helps cement Samsung's position in this area."Dish Network Gets MarriedDish Network (DISH) will merge with someone in 2016, says Phillip Swann, president of TVPredictions.com."The nation's second-largest satellite TV service needs help to stay competitive, and that assistance can only come from a merger," Swann wrote. Possible merger partners include T-Mobile (TMUS), Verizon, Amazon.com (AMZN) and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google."Out of full disclosure, I have predicted in the past that Dish will merge with someone, and it hasn't happened yet," Swann said. "But this time, well, this time I really think it will happen."RELATED:Apple 2016 Predictions: Acquisitions, Accessories.Cloud, Virtual Reality Among Top Tech Trends For 2016.

The competition to attract eyeballs got more intense Tuesday as the YouTube unit of Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) has announced the launch of YouTube TV."Half the cost of cable with zero commitments" said the announcement. For $35 a month, with no commitments or long-term contracts, YouTube TV will include live streaming of ABC, CBS, NBC, Fox, ESPN and about 30 of the biggest cable TV channels."YouTube TV will be available soon in the largest U.S. markets and will quickly expand to cover more cities across the country," YouTube said in a blog post.By visiting tv.youtube.com, consumers can sign up to find out when they'll launch in designated markets.Alphabet stock closed Tuesday at 844.93, down 0.6% on the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: New products or services are part of the N in IBD's CAN SLIM investing system. Strong earnings growth (the C and A in the CAN SLIM System) is the No. 1 factor to look for in a stock, but new products or services are what ultimately generates stellar profitability.The $35 price includes six accounts, so that each user receives a personalized account and recommendations. The service will also allow users to record shows, which will be stored in the cloud."Your cloud DVR can record as many shows as you want, simultaneously, without using precious data or space on your phone and we'll store each of your recordings for nine months," Google said.Missing from the YouTube TV streaming lineup are channels from Viacom (VIAB), Turner Broadcasting, AMC Networks (AMCX) and Discovery Communications (DISCA).RELATED:Comcast, YouTube Set-Top App Deal Excludes New 'Unplugged' Service

Walt Disney's (DIS) "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" has already bumped "Avatar" as the highest-grossing movie of all time in North America, but how Han Solo and company will fare in China isn't a sure thing. Even with a Saturday premiere, MKM Partners said the industry sees the film making over $150 million on its opening weekend on screens in China.Estimates vary widely. According to The Hollywood Reporter, which polled several Chinese theater chain CEOs, the latest installment of the sci-fi epic is expected to bring in around $200 million-$330 million.The upper end of that range would be on par with Viacom 's (VIAB) Paramount release "Transformers: Age of Extinction," the No. 1 movie in China in 2014, but not quite the record-breaking $380 million hauled in by last year's "Furious 7," the seventh "The Fast and the Furious" movie and the No. 2 China box-office record holder, from Comcast's (CMCSA) Universal Pictures."China is the second-biggest movie market in the world, (but) I think that there's a little bit of a question mark," Rentrak (RENT) senior media analyst Paul Dergarabedian told IBD. "'Star Wars' doesn't have a major history there."The original Lucasfilm trilogy of the late '70s and early '80s was reportedly not widely released in the country. And "The Force Awakens" traffics heavily in nostalgia and throwbacks to the original series, which has delighted long-time fans but may go over the heads of first-time viewers.Dergarabedian said that there's "some question" as to how strongly the film will resonate in China. Disney has been assertively building up hype in China prior to the film's release.Disney also agreed in October to give Chinese Internet giant Tencent (TCEHY) the streaming rights to the first six movies to generate interest ahead of "The Force Awakens."The genre is at least known to be popular. Space dramas "tend to do well" in China, said Dergarabedian.Plus, the massive fan-love that "The Force Awakens" has been getting on Twitter (TWTR) and other social media outlets may pique Chinese viewers' interest."Certainly the news of all these box office records and tweets and reviews and positive information about this movie is going to help the film," he said. "This will be a really big marketplace for 'Star Wars,' whether or not it can get into that $400 million range."Shares of Disney closed down 0.3% in the stock market Friday. Tencent shares rallied 0.4%. Imax (IMAX), which has enjoyed big business from "The Force Awakens" and has a growing footprint in China, rose 1.6%.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.RELATED:Pre-China, 'Star Wars' Already Hits $1 Bil Globally'Star Wars' Earns $529 Mil; 'Jurassic' Record Extinct.
